I can understand why some people don't believe in macroevolution since people explain it so poorly.  Cheetahs are an example of a cat turning into something other than a cat.  They are the only living species of cat that don't have a cutaneous sheath around their claws.   Imagine that you came up with a list of all the characteristics that an animal has to have in order to be 100% cat.  Let's say that having a cutaneous sheath is one of those characteristics.  Just to make the math easy, let's say that your list contains 20 characteristics and that the cheetah has the other 19 characteristics.  Wouldn't that make cheetahs only 95% cat?  Now, all cats belong to the family felidae.  Since cheetahs arent 100% cat, do they really belong to the family felidae?  Personally, I think the cut off point should be at least 50%... anything at least 50% cat belongs to the family felidae.  However, it's arbitrary.   A lot of people don't know this, but the species taxon is the only taxon that is found in nature... everything else, including the family taxon, are man-made.  I can't overestimate how important it is for you to understand and accept that last sentence.  Think about it in order to understand it's implications. None of the species of cat alive today are 100% cat unless you simply define one of the species as being 100% cat.  It's your right to do so, since again, it's totally man-made.  But as soon as you define one species as being 100% cat then that automatically means that none of the others are 100% cat.   To make matters worse, some of those 20 characteristics that cats have may be subjective and not completely black and white.  For example, let's say that being agile was one of your 20 characteristics.  There are over 40 species of cats still alive today.  Surely some of them are more agile than others. What if the cheetah is only 80% agile?  Wouldn't that bring down it's cat percentage down to 94% (5 x .80 = 4)?  And surely, if you believe in speciation, in a few hundred thousand years a new species can arise from the cheetah that only has 18 characteristics.  So it's even less of a cat than the cheetah and even closer to that 50% cut off point that I previously mentioned.   Now, some people will object by saying that a cutaneous sheath shouldn't be necessary in order for an animal to be considered a cat.  But again, it's a man-made list, and I'm a man, so I can make that decision if I want.  If you don't like my list, then you can certainly make your own list, but surely, if your list is a good list, any future species can lose one or more characteristics until they are less than 50% of whatever animal you are talking about.  In fact, depending on what characteristics are on your list, it's even possible that some species of cats are already less than 50% and don't actually belong in the family felidae.  I mean, it's not as though taxonomists are gods and can't make mistakes.  Perhaps the cheetah currently isn't a cat.  I'm not saying that it isn't at least 50% cat; I'm saying that I don't know and neither do you.  Think about it.

This video missed another method a speciation: Polyploidy events.  Plants, invertebrates and fungi can speciate through Polyploidy events: one to make a chromatid doubled pollen and another to make a doubled egg cell. The resultant offspring will have more chromasomes than it's parents instantly creating a new species.  Examples of this are many, such as the docosaploidy seen in a black mulberry by Kuromigawa.

Speciation is the process by which new species are formed. For a new species to form a group of the species must first be isolated from the population so that mating and reproduction cannot occur. Here are some examples.  Geographic Isolation is when a part of the species is isolated due to some physical barrier, like a mountain range. Behavioral Isolation could be that they are active at different times of the day or they use different mating calls.  If these groups stay isolated, they will evolve independently and eventually form new species.  Did that help?

Another example of speciation: when Europe and Africa split, two populations of the same species of humanoid life forms were separated by geographical means. The population in Africa became modern humans, whereas the guys in Europe went through an ice age and became Neanderthals. However, Moderns ended up migrating out of Africa to the rest of Eurasia, allowing one lineage to enter Neanderthal territory. The moderns were reunited with their "brothers from another mother" early enough that they might've still been able to mate with each other and produce viable offspring. However, modern humans were slightly better at survival, so if those with European heritage bear traces of Neanderthal DNA, the last Neanderthal was likely the parent of a child they had with a modern human. In other words, some people today are what you might call "mutts."

+AlwaysInAtari Is it possible that they would have exactly the same DNA - yes, I suppose - but it wouldn't be probable.   Like really really really not probable.  There are certainly examples of convergent evolution where different organisms evolve similar phenotypes under similar selective pressures.  There are also examples of parallel evolution where individual, isolated populations of an organism evolve in similar ways (sometimes mutations to the same genes) under similar selective pressures even though they do not interact (Astyanax, Sticklebacks for example).  Even in examples of parallel evolution, populations diverge due to genetic drift so they would still have differences in their DNA sequence (neutral evolution).

For the most part this is definitely the case, however thanks to humans and artificial selection, it is possible to have fertile hybrids. For example, take cat hybrids. The foundation cat is a wild cat, which is bred to a domestic cat. The resulting FEMALE offspring are fertile but the males generally are not, So you then take the F 1 females as they are called, and breed them with a domestic male cat to make F2s and so on, but the time you get to F 4 they are pretty much domestic cats that walk a bit on the wild side and can fully breed just like any other domesticated cat. Now some of the wild cat breeds used include the Asian Leopard Cat (Bengals), the Serval (Savannahs), the Jungle Cat usually with Abbysinians (Chausie) for example. There are also wolf hybrids that are created pretty much the same way.   BTW your example of two extremely different dogs interbreeding does happen, When I was growing up, we had a Samoyed named Klondike Queen or Queenie, And she decided her perfect doggy mate was my great grandfather's dog Little Bit. Now Little Bit was half Chihuahua half Toy Fox Terrier. He was larger than those two breeds, and definitely chunkier, but still considerably smaller than a full grown female Samoyed. She would dig a hole and lay in it so he could reach her lol, Obviously if you are breeding a much larger and a much smaller animal, it is best if the female is the larger one. I would not recommend using a smaller female.  We finally had to give up trying to breed Queenie to a full blooded Samoyed and got her spayed.

People usually picture two different but related species meeting each other then trying to mate with each other. There are various physical, environmental, as well as behavioral reasons this does not occur, even among closely related organisms that are different species. Sometimes the song and/or dance is just not right. This happens in allopatric speciation, when two related organisms live in overlapping areas but do not interbreed. They need not be incapable in the sense of being unable to produce fertile offspring, or the sexual apparatus does not match, but incapable under naturally normal circumstances. Loy4list That's not actually evolution, that's extinction.  But if you want to talk about what happens afterwards, that's called "The Bottleneck Effect."    Imagine a really really big glass bottle, and in that bottle are a bunch of beads that are a pretty even spattering of the colors red, blue, and yellow.  Now, we're going to call the entire contents of that bottle the genetic diversity of a population pre-catastrophe.  Now, we're going to pour like four or five of those beads out of the bottle, which will represent a sudden event that kills off a large portion of the species, and the ones we poured out are now representative of the post-catastrophe genetic diversity.  So say we got three reds, a blue, and a yellow one.  Over time, as this new population recovers, reds are going to become much more prominent than blue or yellows in the new population, resulting in a skewing towards that genotype.    Not sure if that's what you were talking about, but yeah.  Bottleneck Effect.

Joshua Holbrook When a pair mate, their chromosomes are chopped up and switched around at random points on the chromosomes.  This is called genetic shuffling (see http://evolution.berkeley.edu/evosite/evo101/IIIC5aShufflingdetails.shtml). This shuffling requires that the genes be highly the same structurally between the two individuals; if they aren't, genes can be functionally broken, causing a dead foetus. I have seen it estimated that about 1/3 of all human matings die before the fertilized egg even implants for this reason.   Fortunately, most mutations are harmless or possibly even helpful. Those that are deletory kill the result. The branches of sapiens and neanderthals were both still very compatible, enough so that they could successfully interbreed generally.  That is all that need be said.

andytallman101 No. Speciation happens to groups of beings, not individuals. A group will speciate from another when the interbreeding essentially stops, whatever the reason. Eventually, as a result, they will cease to be interfertile, making the speciation event complete.   There are long been a controversy as to whether Neanderthals were Homo neanderthalensis, or Homo sapiens neanderthalensis. The latter appears now to be the case: they are a variety of H. sap, and were not a separate species, just as dachshunds are a variety of gray wolf.   Here is the kicker: speciation and the concept of species are invented by man. Nature doesn't know or care, and man can only use the definition in a provisional, non-absolutist (sometime excessively so) way. That is science for you, ambiguity is often an integral part of the game. Be aware.

"This doesn't prove that 1 species can evolve into a completely different kind of animal."  Evolution does not permit organisms to change into "completely different 'kinds' of animals". This is based on a fundamental misunderstanding of evolution but ultimately taxonomy as well. Besides the fact that you used terms with no scientific definition, I'll do my best to explain this. First off, "kind" refers to nothing. It is not a scientific term, it is not clear what this term describes, and it therefore should not be used in this context. Nevertheless, organisms never evolve out of their respective taxa. A tiger is a feliforme, but neither its ancestors nor its descendants have stopped or will stop being mammals. In other words, every organism in the Tigers evolutionary lineage both past and future will never be a "completely different kind of animal". But again, we have undefined terms. What exactly is a "completely different kind of animals"? Even a Tiger and a Crocodile share characteristics.  "As you said, a chihuahua could still breed with a wolfhound(not that that would happen, but they COULD produce fertile offspring) so why is it that humans cannot breed with chimps or bonobos?"  The potential for two isolated populations to produce fertile offspring is determined by their chromosomal relationship and the recency of their divergence. Chihuahuas and wolfhounds share the same number of chromosomes and their divergence was relatively recently. While it is possible for two organisms from populations with varying pairs of chromosomes to produce the occasional fertile offspring (30 documented cases of fertile mules in the last few centuries), it is a rarity and is not the only determining factor nor the most important. African wild dogs, for instance, share 78 chromosomes with wolves, domesticated dogs, coyotes, etc... but cannot interbreed with any. To your point, the simple fact is that we don't know if humans can interbreed with bonobos or chimps, nobody has ever really tried besides a deranged soviet scientist and it's not clear if his methods were concrete. What does it matter anyway? Just because we share an evolutionary relationship with these two species doesn't mean we must be capable of interbreeding.  "And as far as evolution happening at an imperceptibly slow pace, we should still be able to see evolution happening on a cellular level at least every 20 years. But we don't."  Evolution is a system of population mechanics and inheritance. In what universe would a single gene spread throughout an entire population of 7 billion people in one generation?

CaveFreediving Alright. There is evidence that evolution is a thing. We have the fossil record which can be used to look at earlier species, the chemical composition of organisms (I'm going with organisms here because animals only applies to those organisms within kingdom Animalia, but does not include bacteria, protists, and the like) which can be compared to see how similar it is across species, homologous structures can be used to compare similarities and differences between species, geographic distributions of related species, and the recorded genetic change in organisms over a span of several generations. (source: http://anthro.palomar.edu/evolve/evolve_3.htm) So speciation. First we need to define what a species is. There is still some debate over what exactly a species is, but the most accepted definition is: A group of actually or potentially interbreeding organisms whose offspring will produce fertile offspring. Pretty much the babies can make babies. Once speciation occurs the two species generally cannot reproduce together because of various barriers. The barriers may be that their genetic code is too different to go through mitosis and meiosis without serious problems, or they reproduce differently. For example, we (humans) cannot reproduce with robins because the reproduction methods are different. Humans have sexual intercourse which involves penetration while birds have sexual intercourse but with no penetration (the males actually give females sacks of sperm which the females place inside a canal of sorts). Since the reproduction methods are different, humans could not reproduce with birds. There's also the issue of size: Humans are much bigger than birds. Now, species can actually recombine into one species (which is a totally different form of speciation) and sometimes two species can create hybrids. Mostly the hybrids are sterile and very compromised in terms of health. To sum up species can't reproduce with each other because of behavioral differences, genetic differences, reproduction differences, parts don't match, or geographic isolation. Now, I do agree with you on the dog breeding example. It can't really be used to prove speciation, but it is a handy example of how variation can occur and how selection (in this case artificial selection) can happen. We have actually observed evolution in action with fruit flies and organisms with sort generation periods. With fruit flies we can watch speciation happen because a generation period is relatively short and they produce lots of offspring. Since generation period is short we can observe a genetic change as it passes through the generations in a small period of time, say 10 generations in a week. That's enough time to see how the trait affects the adaption of the organism to the environment. This is, of course, an example of artificial selection. The part of evolution that takes million of years is the change in whole kingdoms and the bigger classifications of organisms (domain, phylum, kingdom, class). Sometimes speciation takes million of years because of environmental conditions (environment refers to anything that affects the organisms. That is ecosystem, other organisms, weather patterns, food, etc) fluctuating quite a bit. Scientists have lots of evidence of evolution. It may be called a theory, but in science a theory is when a hypothesis has enough evidence to be considered fact and thus other hypotheses are based off of it. Evolution is a scientific theory meaning that its scientific fact. It's is not, however, a scientific law. In order to be a law, we (scientists) must be able to predict that it will happen and then observe it happening. We have proof that verifies evolution, but we have no way of predicting when it may happen or how it will happen. This is unlike gravity where we can predict that if we drop a bowling ball from a certain height that it will hit the ground at a certain speed and time. Just because evolution is called a theory does not mean it is not fact. If it was a hypothesis it could be disproven.  And scientists can't directly observe evolution, but we observe its affects. It's like wind. We can't directly observe it (with vision), but we can observe its affects upon the world and measure those affects.

Evolutionists state that mutation is needed to produce "new" DNA information for natural selection to choose from which would cause evolution from one type of animal to another type.   That seems to make sense except that most mutations are harmful and build up over generations decreasing the functionality of the species, thus causing de-evolution. "That seems to make sense except that most mutations are harmful and build up over generations decreasing the functionality of the species"  The harmful mutations dont build up- they are HARMFUL. By the laws of natural selection, that means that the original, non-harmful form of the gene will outcompete the harmful version and it will cease to exist, save perhaps as a recessive allele somewhere in the genome. That why nearly every single genetic disease is recessive- because if someone is only a carrier of the gene, then it remains and may be passed on to offspring. Dominant genetic diseases are /extremely rare/, because dominant genes are always expressed, and so the animal will have the disease. Diseased animals either die, have very few offspring, or dont breed entirely.

Mia Smith Natural selection is not a magic wand to eliminate the bad and keep the good. An animal that survives long enough to reproduce can still have bad mutations. Even if a "good" mutation is passed on, there is no guarantee that the animal doesn't also have bad mutations in its DNA. You should do some research on mutations and you'll see what I mean.

Biochemistry often does not cooperate with the artificial distinctions like species that humans like to make.  There are many examples of different kinds of animals that can, but often do not, breed together successfully.  Often a hybrid can breed with a parent species but not another hybrid. Hybrid females are often fertile while males are sterile.  There is often a spectrum, where a some varieties breed very well with multiple other varieties that can never breed successfully with each other.

Dogs are not considered a different species from wolves, but a subspecies.  All domesticated dogs are in the subspecies Canis Lupus Familiaris. There are 37 recognized subspecies of Grey Wolf, including domesticated dogs, dingos (feral descendants of domesticated dogs), Eurasian Wolves, Tundra Wolves, Arabian Wolves, etc.  Red wolves may be a hybrid species of grey wolves and coyotes.  Species boundaries are often messy. Some types can breed with different types that cannot breed with each other

Saying "non-dogs don't have the genetic information to produce dogs" misses the point. Genomes have no knowledge of species or taxonomy; that's all a framework humans invent to understand nature. Consider gray wolves: each individual has a genotype that is expressed as a phenotype. Natural selection acts on the phenotype. Some genes get passed on, some don't. Eventually a group of wolves gets isolated. Speciation occurs, and that group drifts toward looking more like the dogs we see today.

You're thinking about the "gene pool" as though it's some fixed thing, like a swimming pool filled with water that is slowly being siphoned away. This is not the case; in fact, over time, organisms have gained more genetic information, usually through gene duplication (there's a very well written wikipedia article on this), which is believed to play a major role in evolution. That said, the process of accumulating new genes through duplication is a separate process from speciation.

Also, don't think of evolution like a ladder, with rungs bringing you from one species to another. Think of it like a tree: traveling up along the branches is traveling from parent to child in some population, and branches split when isolation occurs. It's not even clear that if you travel back from Homo sapien you get to Homo erectus; they may have been on a different branch "tip" than Homo sapien, which if you travel backwards gives us a common ancestor, but doesn't make us direct descendants.

This question inherently stems from a misconception about evolution and speciation. Evolution is not a discrete process; there aren't "steps" or "stages" where if we've found every step, we'll fill all the slots and have a perfect picture. It's a nearly continuous process. If some day we find a fossil that belongs where you suggest, then there will be two more fossils to find. We'll never find a fossil of every individual going all the way back, so we'll never have a complete picture.
